title-group.article-title: Small Business Loan Turndowns, Personal Wealth, and Discrimination*

contrib-group.aff: Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System

permissions.copyright-statement: © 2005 by The University of Chicago. All rights reserved.

abstract.p: We examine the impact of personal wealth on small business loan turndowns across demographic groups. Information on home ownership, home equity, and personal net worth, in combination with a rich set of explanatory variables, furthers our understanding of the credit market experiences of small businesses across demographic groups. We find substantial unexplained differences in denial rates between African‐American‐, Hispanic‐, Asian‐, and white‐owned firms. We find that greater personal wealth is associated with a lower probability of loan denial. However, even after controlling for personal wealth, large differences in denial rates across demographic groups remain.

fn.p: We thank Richard America, Robert Avery, Glenn Canner, Edward Ettin, Myron Kwast, Robin Prager, Gregory Price, Alicia Robb, and an anonymous referee for helpful discussion and Douglas Rohde for excellent research assistance. The views expressed herein are those of the authors. They do not necessarily reflect the opinions of the Federal Reserve Board or its staff.

sec.label: I.
sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Recent evidence finds large differences in loan denials between small firms owned by white men and other demographic groups (Cavalluzzo and Cavalluzzo1998; Bostic and Lampani1999; Cavalluzzo, Cavalluzzo, and Wolken2002; Blanchflower, Levine, and Zimmerman2003). The key question is this: Why? In this paper, we do two things to help shed light on this important question. First, we examine the role of personal wealth for explaining loan turndowns across demographic groups. Recent developments in information technology and credit scoring have made the owner's personal wealth an integral part of small business lending decisions (Mester1997; Mann1998). Second, we provide a quantitative assessment of the impact of differences in personal wealth, as well as in the endowments of other key variables in the lending decision, on the differences in denial rates across demographic groups.

We find that personal wealth is important in the decision to extend credit to small businesses. In particular, home ownership is associated with approximately a 30% reduction in the predicted probability of loan denial. However, the amount of equity in the home and the personal wealth of the owner excluding the home play only a modest role in predicting loan turndowns. Furthermore, even after including information on personal wealth in our analysis of loan turndowns, we find substantially higher denial rates among African‐American‐, Hispanic‐, and Asian‐owned businesses, relative to those owned by white men, and modest evidence that African‐American denial rates increase with lender market concentration.

Our quantitative assessment indicates that differences in endowments explain about a third of the univariate difference in denial rates across demographic groups. But personal wealth explains only a small amount of the difference in denial rates between African‐American‐ and white‐owned small businesses. Differences in credit history explain most of the endowment effect between African‐Americans and whites. In contrast, variation in personal wealth accounts for a more substantial part of the difference in denial rates between Hispanic‐ or Asian‐owned businesses and white‐owned firms. In sum, we conclude that personal wealth does little to rule out discrimination as a potential explanation for the observed differences in denial rates across demographic groups.

sec.label: II.
sec.title: Personal Wealth and Lending Decisions
sec.p: Mann (1998) argues that recent advances in information technology have made the owner's personal wealth an integral part of lending decisions in small business credit markets. The key to these developments is the insight that the personal financial strength of the owner is a good indicator of the likelihood that the small business will repay its debts. Some benefits to lenders in considering the owner's personal wealth are that small businesses often have so few hard assets that an underwriting approach focusing only on the business often provides little useful information for predicting the probability of loan default. Importantly, the development in the use of credit scoring for small business loans suggests that it is a lot easier to assess information about the financial strength of the owner than about the assets of the business. This is because it is substantially easier to standardize information about individuals than about business assets. Personal wealth may also serve as a signal of credit quality, and to the extent personal assets are at stake, greater personal wealth may alleviate moral hazard problems, thereby increasing the likelihood of loan repayment (Avery, Bostic, and Samolyk1998).

To understand better the role of personal wealth in small business lending decisions, we visited several local banks to discuss their application procedures.1Application procedures vary markedly across institutions. Some banks request information on only the personal financial strength of the principal owner. Others request information on both the owner and the business, while still others require in addition at least 2 years of both personal and business tax forms. Some banks ask for far less information, requesting only general information on the principal owner. These banks said that they tend to rely almost entirely on the credit history and credit score of the principal owner or business or both.

Appendix Ashows a representative small business loan application. The application requests detailed information on the personal and business assets of the principal owner, her liabilities, references from suppliers, and whether there are any judgments against the owner or business. We used this information to guide us in our variable selection for our empirical models. We also note that Gibson (1983) finds (and our interviews with loan officer's confirmed) that many banks calculate financial ratios, such as the debt‐to‐asset ratio, to assess the probability of repayment. As such, we also include several financial ratios in our regression models.2

The loan officers we spoke with take the prospect of discrimination very seriously. All loan officers were trained in the Community Reinvestment Act (CRA) and other legislation designed to eliminate discrimination from the marketplace. Many loan officers claimed that since the CRA, they have encouraged all potential applicants to apply for credit. Decision making is then centralized at the bank's main office. Penalties against parties that are found to be engaging in discrimination are stiff and can include large settlements and jail time.3

Two recent papers investigating differences in denial rates across demographic groups are particularly relevant for this study. Using the 1993 National Survey of Small Business Finance, Cavalluzzo et al. (2002) found large differences in denial rates between African‐American‐ and white‐owned businesses. They also found evidence that denial rates for business loans to African‐Americans increased with lender market concentration. But personal wealth information was unavailable on their data set. Using both the1993and1998Survey of Small Business Finances, Blanchflower et al. (2003) also found large differences in denial rates between white‐ and minority‐owned businesses. However, Blanchflower et al. did not examine the role of personal wealth in small business lending decisions. Further, none of these papers provides a quantitative assessment of the differences in endowments on loan turndowns across demographic groups.

fn.p: Specifically, we visited four banks in the Washington, D.C., metropolitan area during November 2002, and six banks prior to conducting the1998Survey of Small Business Finances. The discussion in this and the following two paragraphs is based on these visits.

The main difference between the representative loan application in Appendix A and the data provided by the1998Survey of Small Business Finances is the level of detail in the loan application. For example, while the 1998 survey provides information on the owner's wealth, the loan application requests detailed information on many sources of income of the applicant. We, of course, assume that the business is the primary source of income for the applicant. That said, the1998Survey of Small Business Finances simply does not provide some information, such as the face amount of the applicant's life insurance. As such, we cannot exclude omitted variables as a possible source of observed differences.

Historically, discrimination has been hard to prove (Martell et al.1997). To investigate discrimination in the marketplace, state and federal bank regulators examine samples of loan applications, lending decisions, and loan pricing; conduct statistical analyses; and look for irregularities or inconsistencies in the data to see if some groups are being treated differently than others. Given the penalties associated with being found guilty of discrimination, it is possible that loan officers may go out of their way to make sure minorities are not denied loans. To the extent such behavior exists, it should bias against finding lower denial rates for minorities relative to whites.

sec.label: III.
sec.title: The Data
sec.p: We use data from the recently released 1998 Survey of Small Business Finances to examine the role of personal wealth on small business loan denial rates across demographic groups, for those firms that applied for credit within 3 years of the interview date. In addition to the rich set of variables used in prior work on small business loan turndowns, the 1998 survey provides newly available information on the business owner's personal wealth, including home ownership, the extent of equity in the home, and the personal net worth of the owner excluding his home. We supplement these data with Dun and Bradstreet firm credit (risk) scores4and information furnished by the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System on the level of bank concentration in the firm's local area.

The1998Survey of Small Business Finances is among the most extensive public data sets available on small business finances. The survey asks respondents to report on their borrowing experiences within the preceding 3 years. Of the 3,561 firms in the sample, 948 firms applied for credit during this period: 197 minority‐owned businesses (74 African‐American, 73 Hispanic, and 54 Asian owned), and 751 white‐owned businesses. In addition to the information on personal wealth, the 1998 survey provides extensive information on the firm and owner that we use to estimate loan turndowns. This includes the self‐reported credit history of the firm and its owner, financial and other characteristics of the firm (such as the firm's age, geographic location, level of employment, industry, ownership and management characteristics, capital structure, income and balance sheet data). These data allow us to construct many of the variables contained in the loan application presented inAppendix A. Notwithstanding the vast amount of information on the 1998 survey, we note that the level of detail is even greater on the sample application.5

fn.p: The Dun and Bradstreet credit scores used in this study are based only on business information.
This is just one reason some authors have been reluctant to conclude discrimination using the1993and1998Surveys of Small Business Finances. Other reasons are discussed in our conclusions.

sec.title: Descriptive Statistics
sec.p:
Table 1, panel A presents denial rates for all firms and by home ownership across demographic groups. Minority‐owned businesses had significantly higher denial rates than those owned by whites. In particular, African‐Americans were denied credit at more than 2 \documentclass{aastex} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{bm} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{pifont} \usepackage{stmaryrd} \usepackage{textcomp} \usepackage{portland,xspace} \usepackage{amsmath,amsxtra} \usepackage[OT2,OT1]{fontenc} \newcommand\cyr{ \renewcommand\rmdefault{wncyr} \renewcommand\sfdefault{wncyss} \renewcommand\encodingdefault{OT2} \normalfont \selectfont} \DeclareTextFontCommand{\textcyr}{\cyr} \pagestyle{empty} \DeclareMathSizes{10}{9}{7}{6} \begin{document} \landscape $\frac{1}{2}$ \end{document} times the rate of whites, while Hispanics and Asians were denied credit at about twice the rate of whites.6Denial rates for all demographic groups increased substantially without home ownership. Denial rates for firms whose principal owner did not own a home were about twice those of others. Table 1

signify that the statistic is significantly different from the white‐owned firm value at the 90%, 95%, and 99% level of confidence, respectively.

Panel B provides information on the business owner's personal wealth. Almost 9 out of 10 business owners owned their home. Home ownership rates were about the same for white and African‐American business owners. In contrast, about 72% of Hispanic and 73% of Asian business owners owned their home, significantly less than the percentage for whites.

Home equity and personal net worth also varied across demographic groups. Home equity and personal net worth were greater for white business owners than for other demographic groups. For example, the mean (median) value of personal net worth was $687,719 ($150,000) for white business owners compared to $159,962 ($80,000) for African‐American owners of firms.

fn.p: These estimates are similar to those reported in Blanchflower et al.2005.

sec.label: IV.
sec.title: Empirical Approach
sec.p:
We estimate the probability that a firm was denied credit at least once during the last 3 years, given that the firm applied for new credit during the period.7Consistent with prior research, we control for the characteristics of the firm and owner, the owner's self‐reported credit history, information on relationships with financial institutions and suppliers, geographic location, and industry classification. We include proxies for the level of local lender market concentration and a credit score obtained from Dun and Bradstreet.Table 2presents all variables and definitions employed in our analysis. Descriptive statistics for many of these variables are provided inAppendix B. Table 2
Variables and Definitions.
Dependent Variable
DENIED Set to 1 if the firm was denied credit anytime within the 3 years of the survey interview date, 0 otherwise. Defined only for those firms that applied for credit in the past 3 years.
Independent Variables
Personal wealth:
HOME Indicates whether the firm's principal owner owns his or her own home
HEQ1 (2, 3) Owns home and equity $1 to $50,000 ($50,000 to $150,000; ≥$150,000). HEQ0 = does not own home (omitted)
NETW1 (2, 3, 4) Personal net worth $1 to $50,000 ($50,000 to $250,000; $250,000 to $1,000,000; ≥$1,000,000); NETW0 = 1 for firms with 0 or negative net worth (omitted)
Lender market structure:
HHI Herfindahl‐Hirshman bank deposit index of banking market concentration, 1999; defined for the MSA or rural county of the firm's main office
Credit history and credit score:
BANKRUPT Indicates whether the firm's principal owner declared bankruptcy within the preceding 7 years
BDELINQ1 (2, 3) Indicates whether the firm's principal owner was 60 or more days delinquent on business obligations 1 time (2 times, 3 or more times) within the preceding 3 years (0 times omitted)
PDELINQ1 (2, 3) Indicates whether the firm's principal owner was 60 or more days delinquent on personal obligations 1 time (2 times, 3 or more times) within the preceding 3 years (0 times omitted)
JUDGMENT Indicates judgments against the principal owner within the preceding 3 years
CREDIT_SCORE Credit score percentile, created by Dun & Bradstreet as of May 1999
Owner characteristics:
NOT_HS (COLLEGE) Indicates whether the firm's principal owner did not graduate high school (some college)
EXPER Number of years of experience the owner has owning or managing a business
MANAGE Indicates whether the firm is managed on a daily basis by the owner or a partner
OWNSHR Percentage of the firm that is owned by the principal owner
Firm/relationship characteristics:
LNASSET Natural log of total firm assets
LNTOTEMP Natural log of the total number of employees
SALEASST Sales/total assets
LIABASST Total short‐ and long‐term debts/total assets
PROFASST Operating profits/total assets
LNAGE Natural log of firm age at the time of the survey
CCORP (SCORP, PARTNER) Indicates whether the firm is a C‐corporation (S‐corporation, partnership); proprietorship omitted
NATN (OUTSD, REG) Indicates whether the firm's primary sales or delivery of products are throughout the United States (outside the United States within the same geographic region, or in the same local area [omitted]) as the firm's main office
MSA Indicates whether the firm's headquarters are located in an MSA versus rural area
REL_PRIM Number of years the firm has been conducting business with its primary institution (set to 0 if the firm has no primary institution); the primary institution is the source the firm reports as being its main or primary supplier of financial services
SOURCES Number of institutions that the firm uses for all its financial services
TCUSE Indicates whether the firm uses trade credit
CHECKING Indicates whether the firm has any checking accounts
SAVING Indicates whether the firm has any savings accounts
PRIM_FIN Indicates whether the firm's primary institution is a financial institution
LOAN Indicates whether the firm has loans other than the most recent loan
The estimates also include indicators for demographic groups (AFAM, HISPANIC, ASIAN, GENDER), nine one‐digit SIC industry controls (primary manufacturing excluded) and nine regional variables (New England excluded).

We compare results from four specifications of the model. The first is a baseline model that includes all the variables intable 2(save personal wealth) as well as bivariate demographic indicators. We call this a baseline model because it most closely resembles the type of model that traditionally has been reported in the literature on the economics of credit market discrimination (see Blanchflower et al.2005). The second specification augments the first with interactions between demographic groups and market concentration (see Cavalluzzo et al.2002). Denial rates that increase with lender market concentration at a greater rate for the disadvantaged group than the favored group are consistent with Becker's (1957) fundamental theory of discrimination.8

Our third specification adds an indicator for home ownership (HOME). Home ownership may provide a signal of credit quality to lenders, potentially mitigating adverse selection problems common in lending markets. Additionally, to the extent lenders can lay claim to the personal assets of the owners (e.g., via explicit loan covenants, collateral, or personal guarantees), home ownership may alleviate moral hazard problems associated with the decision to extend credit to small business owners.

Our final specification includes information on the extent of equity in the home and the net worth of the principal owner excluding the home. Because of the skewness in our personal wealth data (seetable 1) and to control for the difficulty respondents may have in accurately reporting their personal wealth, we estimate our models with indicator variables for the extent of home equity and personal net worth. We include three indicators for home equity (HEQ1–HEQ3): the business owner owns a home and home equity is less than $50,000 (HEQ1), $50,000 to less than $150,000 (HEQ2), and $150,000 or more (HEQ3). The excluded group is firm owners who do not own their home. We use four indicators to characterize personal net worth (NETW1–NETW4): personal net worth between $1 and $49,000, $50,000–$249,999, $250,000–$999,999, and $1,000,000 or more. The excluded group includes firm owners with zero or negative net worth.

fn.p: All presented results are conditional on the firm applying for credit. To the extent self‐selection by applicants or prescreening by lenders at the application stage exists, conditional estimates may provide biased estimates of a firm's access to credit. In particular, if self‐selection or prescreening varies by demographic group, then the differentials may be biased as well. To address this possibility, we also estimated a bivariate probit with sample selection, using the variable APPLY (set to 1 if the firm recently applied for credit, 0 otherwise) as the dependent variable in the selection equation. Because the1998Survey of Small Business Finances does not provide any variables correlated with loan applications but not loan denials, we rely on the nonlinearly of the selection equation to identify the estimated parameters of the model (Bloom, Preiss, and Trussell1983). The correlation between our selection (application) equation and denial equation was statistically insignificant, indicating it was unnecessary to estimate a joint model.
See Cavalluzzo et al. (2002) for additional discussion and limitations of this argument.

sec.title: Denial Analysis, Demographic Group, and Market Structure
sec.p: Other factors influencing the probability a firm was denied credit include the HHI (firms located in more concentrated markets are more likely to be denied credit) and the firm's credit history. In particular, all the self‐reported credit history variables (bankruptcy, personal and business delinquencies, and judgments) are significant. In contrast, the credit score, which is insignificant, appears to capture much of the information already reported in the self‐reported credit history variables. The credit score is significant at the 5% level when the other information on credit history is excluded from the estimation (not shown).

Owner characteristics (apart from demographic group), firm characteristics (apart from the firm's profit‐to‐asset ratio and national sales area), and information on relationships with financial institutions and suppliers are unrelated to the decision to extend small businesses credit. These results were confirmed by Wald tests that were insignificant for the three groups of characteristics and are particularly surprising given that much of this information is contained on our sample loan application inAppendix A. The insignificant coefficients on many of these variables are consistent with statements by loan officers who said that they rely on credit history and credit scores.

Column 2 augments the model in column 1 with interactions between lender market concentration and demographic group. In this model, a specific race effect (e.g., African‐American) requires that the intercept dummy (e.g., AFAM) and its interaction with the HHI (AFAM*HHI) be jointly significantly different from 0. Using this criterion, there were significant African‐American, Hispanic, and Asian effects; the three demographic variables and their interaction with the HHI are jointly significant at the 95% level or better.

Consistent with Cavalluzzo et al. (2002), we find modest evidence that denial rates of African‐Americans increased with lender market concentration relative to those of whites. The coefficient on AFAM*HHI is positive and significant at the 10% level. Surprisingly, denial rates of Hispanics decreased with lender market concentration.10Additional analysis of this unexpected result indicate that it is driven by four Hispanic observations in concentrated markets that were never denied credit. The interaction between ASIAN and HHI is statistically insignificant, indicating that differentials between Asian‐ and white‐owned businesses did not vary with lender market concentration.11

To get a sense of the role for lender market concentration on denial rates across demographic groups,table 4, panel A, presents the mean predicted probability of loan denial for each demographic group at different values of HHI, based on the model intable 3, column 2. At all levels of HHI, denial rates of African‐Americans‐, Hispanics, and Asians exceeded those of whites. At the 25th percentile of the HHI distribution, denial rates of African‐Americans (Hispanics, Asians) denial rates are 18 (22, 18) percentage points greater than those of white men. In contrast, at the 75th percentile of the HHI distribution, denial rates of African‐Americans (Hispanics, Asians) are 31 (9, 17) percentage points greater than those of whites.12
Table 4

fn.p: A minority variable set to 1 if the firm was minority owned (0 otherwise) provided similar results. Because of differences in the behavior of denial rates with lender concentration across demographic groups, we maintain separate indicator variables for each demographic group.
We note that Cavalluzzo et al. (2002) found that Hispanic denial rates increased with lender market concentration; however, their result is statistically insignificant.

The analysis assumes a linear relation between denial rates and market concentration. We also used an indicator variable for the HHI set to 1 if the market was concentrated (i.e., HHI &gt; 1800), 0 otherwise. This cutoff was used by Cavalluzzo and Cavalluzzo (1998) to indicate a concentrated market when the continuous measure was unavailable. All the demographic interaction terms with the HHI indicator variable are statistically insignificant.

Comparable magnitudes for African‐Americans and whites are reported by Cavalluzzo et al. (2002) using the 1993 National Survey of Small Business Finance. Cavalluzzo et al. do not find differences for Hispanics and Asians. We estimated several alternative specifications to test the robustness of the results associated with lender market concentration. First, we estimated the models on the subset of firms located only in metropolitan statistical areas (MSAs). Although all our regressions include an MSA control variable, many researchers believe that MSAs represent better economic markets, as rural counties are often defined along political, rather than economic, characteristics. Excluding rural counties could provide a more homogeneous set of markets for analysis. However, it also has the effect of disproportionately removing the most concentrated markets from the analysis. Estimates using just MSAs (not shown) reduce the statistical significance of both AFAM*HHI and HISP*HHI below commonly accepted levels of statistical significance; however, the joint significance of both remains. We also estimated the models excluding firms with greater than $10 million in sales. Larger firms probably have greater financing options available to them, including being potentially more likely to be able to leave their local lending market if faced with difficulty obtaining credit. Also, there are relatively few large minority firms. The results are virtually identical to those presented in table 4. Finally, we varied the definition of the dependent variable to include only denials on the most recent application and only firms that were denied credit on all loan applications within the past 3 years. The joint significance of the demographic variables and their interaction terms remained; however, the positive coefficient on AFAM*HHI was no longer significant at commonly accepted levels.

sec.title: Denial Analysis and Personal Wealth
sec.p: Our next set of estimates investigates the impact of personal wealth on the denial differentials across demographic groups and lender market structure. Column 3 oftable 3augments the estimates in column 2 with an indicator for whether the business owner owns his or her home. Home ownership significantly reduces the probability a firm will be denied credit. The average predicted probability of denial assuming home ownership is 27% versus 39% otherwise. While home ownership plays a role in predicting loan turndowns, it has little effect on the demographic coefficients and their interaction terms. The joint effect of the demographic variables and their corresponding interaction terms maintain both magnitude and statistical significance.13

Column 4 includes variables describing the extent of equity in the home and the net worth of the owner. We find some evidence that home equity and net worth reduce the probability of loan turndowns. All seven of the coefficients for home equity and personal net worth are negatively signed and one (HEQ2) is statistically significant. A Wald test on the group of personal wealth variables is jointly significant at the 10% level.14

One explanation for the modest role for home equity and net worth in predicting denials could be that much of the information may already be contained in other variables in the estimation. To see if this is the case, we reestimated the model in column 4 without the self‐reported credit history variables and credit score (not shown). In this analysis, all the personal wealth indicator variables are statistically negative. Moreover, they are jointly significant at the 1% level.15

Despite the role played by personal wealth in estimating loan turndowns, the effect on the demographic coefficients is limited; the joint effect of all the demographic coefficients and the corresponding interaction terms maintains both magnitude and statistical significance. Moreover, the estimated probabilities of denial at different levels of market concentration are nearly identical, regardless of whether they include the information on personal wealth (seetable 4, panel B).

fn.p: Estimates without the interaction terms (not shown) also provide evidence of a pervasive demographic effect at the 1% level of statistical significance for all demographic groups even after controlling for home ownership. We also interacted HOME with each of our demographic variables to see if the influence of home ownership on denial rates varied across demographic groups. Homeownership significantly reduces the probability of denial for all groups except Asians. Additional comparisons indicate that homeownership significantly reduces denial rates of Hispanics (but not other groups) more than it does those of whites.

We examined several alternative specifications for equity and net worth. We modeled each as linear, log, quadratic, categorical with different cutoffs, and a combined home equity plus net worth variable. Home equity was significant for log, quadratic, and categorical representations. Personal net worth was insignificant for continuous functions of net worth but jointly significant for categorical representations. Results for other estimated coefficients, including the demographic coefficients, were similar to those presented.

It is also possible that personal wealth may be more important in predicting denials for firms with unlimited liability, as the personal assets of the firm are at stake. We find some evidence that this may be the case. The joint effect of the seven personal wealth variables is significant at the 10% level among proprietorships and partnerships but insignificant among corporations.

sec.label: VI.
sec.title: Endowment Effects
sec.p: In the preceding section, we found that credit history and personal wealth significantly influenced the probability of loan denial. Firm, owner, and financial relationship variables were less important. In this section of the paper, we provide a quantitative assessment of the influence of the differences in endowments of our applicants on the differences in small business denial rates across demographic groups. By endowments, we mean the characteristics of the firms and their owners. We also measure the relative importance of the different types of information in the underwriting equation.

sec.title: Total Endowment Effect
sec.p:
Table 5presents our assessment of the impact of differences in endowments on access to credit across demographic groups. Panel A presents estimates fromequation (1)quantifying the total endowment effect. Applying our estimate of \documentclass{aastex} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{bm} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{pifont} \usepackage{stmaryrd} \usepackage{textcomp} \usepackage{portland,xspace} \usepackage{amsmath,amsxtra} \usepackage[OT2,OT1]{fontenc} \newcommand\cyr{ \renewcommand\rmdefault{wncyr} \renewcommand\sfdefault{wncyss} \renewcommand\encodingdefault{OT2} \normalfont \selectfont} \DeclareTextFontCommand{\textcyr}{\cyr} \pagestyle{empty} \DeclareMathSizes{10}{9}{7}{6} \begin{document} \landscape $\beta ^{W}$ \end{document} to all observations, differences in endowments across demographic groups increase the predicted probability of denial for African‐Americans (Hispanics, Asians) by more than 50% (30%, 30%). However, differences in endowments explain only about a third of the original differential in denial rates for all groups relative to firms owned by whites. The remaining difference is due either to differences in treatment or error.17

a
The total endowment effect is calculated as
such that \documentclass{aastex} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{bm} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{pifont} \usepackage{stmaryrd} \usepackage{textcomp} \usepackage{portland,xspace} \usepackage{amsmath,amsxtra} \usepackage[OT2,OT1]{fontenc} \newcommand\cyr{ \renewcommand\rmdefault{wncyr} \renewcommand\sfdefault{wncyss} \renewcommand\encodingdefault{OT2} \normalfont \selectfont} \DeclareTextFontCommand{\textcyr}{\cyr} \pagestyle{empty} \DeclareMathSizes{10}{9}{7}{6} \begin{document} \landscape $X_{i}^{M}$ \end{document} is the characteristic vector for firmiof groupmand \documentclass{aastex} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{bm} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{pifont} \usepackage{stmaryrd} \usepackage{textcomp} \usepackage{portland,xspace} \usepackage{amsmath,amsxtra} \usepackage[OT2,OT1]{fontenc} \newcommand\cyr{ \renewcommand\rmdefault{wncyr} \renewcommand\sfdefault{wncyss} \renewcommand\encodingdefault{OT2} \normalfont \selectfont} \DeclareTextFontCommand{\textcyr}{\cyr} \pagestyle{empty} \DeclareMathSizes{10}{9}{7}{6} \begin{document} \landscape $\beta ^{W}$ \end{document} is the coefficient vector for groupW.
b
The individual endowment effects are calculated using the bootstrapping technique described in Cavalluzzo and Wolken (2002). Personal wealth includes HEQ1–HEQ3 and NETW1–NETW4; Credit history includes BANKRUPT, PDELINQ1–3, BDELINQ1–3, JUDGMENT, and CREDIT_SCORE; owner characteristics include NOT_HS, COLLEGE, EXPER, MANAGE, and OWNSHR; firm characteristics include LNASSET, LNTOTEMP, SALEASST, LIABASST, PROFASST, LNAGE, CCORP, SCORP, PARTNER, NATN, OUTSD, REG, and MSA; and relationship characteristics include REL_PRIM, SOURCES, TCUSE, CHECKING, SAVING, PRIM_FIN, and LOAN.
c
Numbers in parentheses represent the percentage of the original difference in denial rates explained by that set of endowments.

fn.p: One potential source of error is omitted variable bias. In particular, based on our interviews with loan officers, we initially viewed the owner's personal credit score as a potentially important omitted variable. However, a recent industry study by Fair, Isaac (Martell et al.1997) found a 21 percentage point difference in denial rates between low‐to‐moderate‐income areas and high‐income areas, even after including the credit score produced by Fair, Isaac (a score that contains both personal and business information). Assuming that income is highly correlated with demographic characteristics and noting that many of the components of the Fair, Isaac credit score are already included in our analysis and that we have many of the variables that should determine the owner's personal credit score, such as the number of personal delinquencies, bankruptcies, or judgments against the owner, it is unlikely that having access to the owner's personal credit score would explain much of the remaining differences (rough estimates based on the information in the Fair, Isaac study suggest that it would probably explain about 4 percentage points). Rather, interviews with loan officers indicated that greater information on the loan purpose, such as the projected cash flows of the proposed project and being able to validate the self‐reported applicant information, likely provides greater success in explaining the remaining differences. We revisit this discussion in our conclusions.

sec.title: Marginal Endowment Effects
sec.p: Panel B contains our estimates of the impact of the differences in endowments for individual sets of characteristics on loan turndowns across demographic groups. We group the variables into five categories and analyze the marginal endowment effect for each category of variables. The categories are personal wealth, credit history and credit score, firm characteristics, owner characteristics, and relationship characteristics (seetable 5, note b). For example, personal wealth includes HEQ1–HEQ3 and NETW1–NETW4.

Differences in personal wealth account for only a small percentage of the total differential between white‐ and African‐American‐owned firms but account for a much larger portion of the total differential between white‐ and Hispanic‐ or Asian‐owned firms. Indeed, for Asians, differences in personal wealth appear to be the most important factor explaining the differences in denial rates between Asian‐ and white‐owned businesses. The importance of personal wealth in explaining loan turndowns across demographic groups is consistent with the descriptive statistics intable 1and the regression results intable 3. Whites and African‐Americans had fairly similar home ownership rates. Likewise, Hispanics and Asians had significantly lower home ownership rates than whites. Further, our regression analysis found that home ownership was the key personal wealth variable for predicting loan turndowns. Thus, the differences in home ownership observed in the descriptive statistics intable 1and the importance of home ownership in predicting loan turndowns is consistent with our quantitative assessment of the importance of the owner's personal wealth between minority‐ and white‐owned small businesses.

In contrast to the limited role of personal wealth for explaining differences between African‐American‐ and white‐owners of businesses, the credit history of the firm and owner and the credit score of the firm play a substantial role in explaining these differences. Credit history and credit score are also important for explaining differences between Hispanic‐ and white‐owned businesses. These variables explain almost one third (13%) of the original differential between African‐American (Hispanic) and white owners of small businesses. Differences in credit history explain little of the differential for Asians.

Firm characteristics such as firm assets, profit‐to‐assets, and debt‐to‐assets explain an important portion of the differences in denial rates for all demographic groups relative to whites. In contrast, relationship characteristics explain only a small portion of original differential, except, perhaps, for Asian‐owned firms.

sec.label: VII.
sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: Conditional on the firm applying for credit, we found that personal wealth, especially as proxied by home ownership, is important for predicting loan turndowns. When quantifying the impact of personal wealth, we found that it explains more than 10% of the original difference in denial rates for Hispanic‐ and Asian‐owned firms relative to those owned by whites but a much smaller portion of the difference between African‐American and white firms. This result is driven by similar home ownership rates by African‐American and white small business owners but lower home ownership rates among Hispanics and Asians. We found that credit history was far more important for explaining denial differences for African‐American‐owned firms than for other groups. However, even after including this information in our analyses, large differences in loan turndowns between African‐American‐, Hispanic‐, and Asian‐owned small businesses relative to those of whites remain. There is also some evidence that denial rates of African‐Americans increase with lender market concentration.

Despite the long list of variables provided by our data, differences in endowments explained only about a third of the univariate difference in denial rates across demographic group. Could this difference be due to discrimination? While this is certainly one possibility, we found that many banks collect even greater detail on personal and business financial strength than that provided by the1998Survey of Small Business Finances. Indeed, interviews with loan officers indicated that greater information on the loan purpose, such as the projected cash flows of the proposed project and being able to validate the information on the application could help to explain at least some of the remaining differences. Another limitation to concluding discrimination is that our data set is obtained from the small businesses themselves at the time of the survey, rather than from the lending institutions at the time of the loan application. Therefore, some of the details of the firms' circumstances may differ between the time of application and the time the data were collected. We also do not know the underwriting standards applied by each institution; nor do we have information on the characteristics of the loan officers. Given these limitations, we cannot eliminate omitted variable bias as a potential explanation for the observed differences.

In sum, we found that personal wealth, especially home ownership, is important for predicting small business loan turndowns. We found that information on personal wealth explained some differences between Hispanic‐ and Asian‐owned businesses and those owned by whites but almost none for African‐American businesses. Nor did it lessen the influence of lender market concentration on the African‐American differentials. Although the evidence of disparate access associated with lender market concentration is mixed and the cause of the observed disparities are ambiguous, we conclude that information on personal wealth does little to rule out discrimination as a potential explanation for the large differences in denial rates across demographic groups.

I authorize you to make whatever credit inquiries you consider necessary concerning the statements made in this loan application. I agree that the application shall remain your property whether or not the loan is granted. I also agree that you may give information regarding my experience with you to credit bureaus and other proper persons. I have carefully read the answers given above and certify that they are correct to the best of my knowledge. Under penalties of perjury, I certify that I have provided my correct Social Security number/taxpayer identification number and that I am not subject to Internal Revenue Service backup withholding. I understand that I have the right to a copy of any appraisal report used in connection with this application if the loan is to be secured by a dwelling. If I wish a copy, I will write to you at the mailing address you have provided with this application no later than 90 days after you notify me about the action taken on this application or I withdraw this application.
